Definition: In this task, you will receive a text passage from a trivia quiz. You should choose the category that this question belongs to from the following categories: History, Science, Social Science, Fine Arts, Literature. You can only choose one category, so if in doubt, please choose the closest match.

Positive Examples.input: In one work this author details the life of a tomb-maker who makes extra money by playing the organ at an insane asylum, while another of his novels sees Swartz give a refugee proper documentation only after he tells him his life story in the title Portuguese city. In addition to The Black Obelisk and The Night in Lisbon, he also wrote about Robert and Otto selling their auto workshop and visiting Patrice in a Swiss tuberculosis sanatorium in his novel The Three Comrades, while the turbulent life of the German surgeon Ravic is told in The Arch of Triumph. Another of his novels, The Road Back, is thought to be a sequel to his most famous book, in which the patriotic teacher Kantorek convinces Paul Bumer and his friends to join the Germany Army during World War I. For 10 points, name this German author who wrote All Quiet on the Western Front.
Positive Examples.explanation: The text is talking about an author and their works, so it belongs to theliterature category.

Positive Examples.input: In one election, this man attacked Helen Gahagan Douglas by calling her ""the pink lady. "" At the American National Exhibition in Moscow, this man engaged in the ""Kitchen Debate"" with Nikita Khrushchev. After losing a governor's race to Pat Brown, this politician erroneously said the press wouldn't have him to kick around anymore. In another election, this man defended his use of a slush fund with the ""Checkers"" speech. For 10 points, name this former Vice President under Eisenhower, who lost the presidency to John F. Kennedy in 1960, but eventually was elected president in 1968.
Positive Examples.explanation: The text is describing some events that took place in the past, and there's nothing relevant to literature, science or art involved, so the category is history.

Negative Examples.input: A student at Columbia under Clarence White, this artist first gained critical recognition from a group including Imogen Cunningham and Willard Van Dyke. Following World War II, this artist produced such collections as Mormon Villages and The Irish Countryman, and her report with her husband Paul Taylor led to her employment by Roy Stryker, who had hired Esther Bubley for similar reasons. Her work was used in an exhibit on Executive Order 9066, but she remains better known for a work whose title figure remained unknown for forty years until she identified herself as Florence Owens Thompson, a portrait produced as the result of her hiring by the Farm Security Administration. For ten points, identify this photographer who produced some of the most famous images of the Great Depression, including Migrant Mother.
Negative Examples.explanation: Although an artist might contribute to literature, going further through text shows that the mentioned artist is a painter, so the correct label is fine arts.

Negative Examples.input: Published one year before its companion essay Churches and Sects in North America, this works first part describes Martin Luthers introduction of the German word Beruf into his translation of the New Testament. Its second part begins by discussing the inner loneliness and anxiety caused by the doctrine of predestination, leading individuals to seek external signs of their election through tireless labor in a calling. The author then argues that this religious motivation for constant hard work led to the development of the modern economic system, trapping society in a shell as hard as steel. FTP, identify this essay linking Calvinist beliefs to the growth of capitalism by Max Weber.
Negative Examples.explanation: This example is tricky, as it speaks about a written book and can be related to literature, and also contains references to "development of modern economic system", so it can be labeled as history, but the social science label is the best fit to this text.

Instances.input: John Hakac claimed that this poem's "organically complete" third stanza contains "three distinct phases of love". Its speaker makes a comparison to "a magic lantern" which "threw the nerves in patterns on a screen" and describes "the voices dying with a dying fall / Beneath the music from a farther room". Its speaker admits that he is "not Prince Hamlet, nor was meant to be" and says he "should have been a pair of ragged claws / Scuttling across the floors of silent seas". Opening with the line "Let us go then, you and I," it describes the speaker's distaste for women who "come and go / Talking of Michelangelo. " For 10 points, identify this poem by T. S. Eliot.

Jasper Johns's Racing Thoughts and Kaspar Malevich's Solar Eclipse with [this work] both feature recreations of it, the former in black and white and the latter with two red Xs. Fernand Leger created a version "with keys," while E. H. Gombrich pointed out the distinctive sfumato at the corners of the eyes. Margaret Livingstone claimed that this painting's most famous feature is captivating because it is not perceptible by foveal vision and thus nearly disappears when it is looked at directly. Featuring an added mustache in Duchamp's parody L. H. O. O. Q., for 10 points, name this painting famous for its subject's lack of eyebrows and enigmatic smile, a portrait by Leonardo da Vinci.

Marius Petipa choreographed a ballet by this composer in which the title character pricks herself with a needle to activate Carabosse's curse. Another of his ballets contains a recognizable Trepak dance. He composed a ballet in which a prince dances with the black-clad Odile at a ball after mistaking her for the title character, who has been cursed by von Rothbart. This composer used a celesta solo in the "Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy" in a ballet in which Fritz and Clara observe a battle between gingerbread men and the Mouse King. For 10 points, name this composer of the ballets The Sleeping Beauty, Swan Lake, and The Nutcracker.

A ubiquitin ligase that marks specific proteins which the 26S proteasome breaks down is known as its (*) promoting complex, and in plants, the step immediately following it features vesicles moving along the phragmoplast. The step preceding it is ended by inactivation of cyclin dependent kinases, and the kinetochore fibers become shorter during this step. Chromatid pairs separate into identical chromosomes, which are subsequently pulled to the poles by the spindle fibers. FTP, identify this step of cell division that follows metaphase.

In the Introduction to this work, an engineer visits town and asks about the history of the title character that he views there; that serves as the frame for this novel. One fantasy of that title character is to have his stockings mended on a cold winter evening by a woman. The title character's wife was talkative when she married him, but after the death of his mother, she becomes histrionic. She's later able to use her skill as a nurse when her husband crashes into a tree after a sleigh ride. That sleigh ride occurs after the highly symbolic shattering of a red pickle dish by the wife's cat, and that precedes the title character's declaration that he cannot live without Mattie Silver, who's being sent away by Zeena. For 10 points, identify this novella about a stoic Starkfield farmer, a work by Edith Wharton.

The "gene shears" technology is a synthetic one of these molecules that is being developed for the treatment of viruses. One of these molecules regulates cellular production of glucosamine-6-phosphate. Hepatitis D relies on one of these molecules for its replication and viability, and another is used by plant viruses to process the products of rolling circle replication. The latter is a hairpin one of these molecules, a form which, like the hammerhead variety of these, does not require a metal ion to be catalytically active. These molecules are able to catalyze aminotransferase activity, but they are most notable for their ability to cleave themselves and are thought to be evolutionarily related to the spliceosome. For 10 points, give this name for RNA molecules that are able to catalyze chemical reactions.

This figures wife was accused of being Ethiopian by his siblings, after which his sister was stricken with leprosy for seven days. He gained that wife by defeating some shepherds at a well, thus defending the honor of the daughters of the Midianite Jethro. His son Gershom was sent home along with Zipporah when the angel of death came down. His sister was Miriam and his brother, owner of a blooming staff, was Aaron. For ten points, name this Hebrew who paved the way for his people through the Red Sea.

This canvas was commissioned by Madame de Pompadour to hang in the Chteau de Bellevue. Cast against a dark, cloudy background, a cherub on the bottom left retrieves a string of pearls from a half-shell tray, while a dove caresses the feet of the title character. Another cherub attends to the title character's hair, while a third on the right helps the titular figure tie a blue ribbon around a dove in her lap. Depicting the scene of a goddess in her private room, FTP, identify this most famous painting by Franois Boucher.
